titleStmt.title: Telegram from William F. Cody to John H. Tait, December 23, 1913
titleStmt.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

notesStmt.note: Telegram / night letter is typewritten; date appears clearly on accompanying envelope. John H. Tait (c1873-1940) was with the 1st U.S. Volunteer Cavalry (Roosevelt Rough Riders) during the Spanish American War, May 1- September 30, 1898; Tait is listed as a Roosevelt Rough Rider in the 1899 and 1902 BBWW route books but does not appear in the 1900 route book. Harry Heye Tammen (1856-1924) and partner F. G. Bonfils were co-owners and co-editors of the Denver Post; Tammen had various business dealings with WFC, including the making of The Indian Wars. "Gouch" remains unidentified; remote possibility it is George H. Gooch, the compiler of the 1899 route book who worked in BBWW as an assistant fireman and handler of the calcium lights.

bibl.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
bibl.title: Telegram from William F. Cody to John H. Tait

msIdentifier.repository: McCracken Research Library, John Tait Collection

div1.note:
Western Union Night Letter
Western Union Telegraph and Cable
Theo. N. Vail, President
Form 2289 B
Received At
div1.p: Agent Buffalo Bill Albany Hotel Denver Colo
I will arrive Denver on Union Pacific Wednesday evening nine oclocko'clock tell Tammen and Gouch.

div1.note:
Form 1529
Telegraph and Cable Service to All the World.
The Western Union Telegraph Co.
Incorporated
For Quick Service Answer by Bearer
Number
PAID
Pay No Charges on This Message.

back.note: Note 1: Probably a typographical error. Cody commonly signed his name as "W. F. Cody."
Note 2: This penciled notation is in an unknown hand.
